description.narrative: Water and Climate Change information services for Ethiopia (WACCA-Ethiopia) is a country driven initiative to strengthen and accelerate efforts at national and regional levels across Ethiopia in the development of climate and water information and early warning services. Reliable climate information is crucial to meeting key targets in the growth and transformation plans (GTP), nationally determined contributions, as well as the climate resilient green economy (CRGE) strategy. The National Meteorological Agency, the hydrological services under the Ministry of Water, Irrigation and Electricity and the Ministry of the Environment, Forests and Climate Change are charged with the provision of these information and are the local implementing partners in the WACCA-Ethiopia initiative. The common aim is to develop technical capacity and institutional sustainability for the provision of these key services and this initiative is a direct response to this need. It shall also provide tailored information designed to fit end-under needs with the best available knowledge about the future climate, and develop region specific best-practice solutions for adaptation.

Water and Climate Change information services for Ethiopia (WACCA-Etiopien) är ett landsdrivet initiativ för att stärka och påskynda insatser på nationell och regional nivå i Etiopien i utvecklingen av klimat- och vatteninformation samt tidiga varningssystem. Tillförlitlig klimatinformation är avgörande för att möta nyckelmål i Etiopiens utvecklingsplan s.k. Growth and Transformation Plan (GTP II), klimatåtagade s.k. "nationally determined contributions" under klimatavtalet samt Etiopiens climate resilient green economy (CRGE) strategy. National Meteorological Agency, de hydrologiska tjänsterna under Ministry of Water, Irrigation and Electricity och Ministry of the Environment, Forests and Climate Change är skyldiga att tillhandahålla denna information och är de lokala genomförandepartnerna i WACCA-Etiopien. Det gemensamma målet är att utveckla teknisk kapacitet och institutionell hållbarhet för att tillhandahålla dessa nyckeltjänster och detta projekt är ett direkt svar på detta behov. Projektet ska också tillhandahålla skräddarsydd information som utformats för att passa de slutliga användarna med den bästa tillgängliga kunskapen om det framtida klimatet och utveckla regionspecifika lösningar för bästa praxis för anpassning.

description.narrative: Following a 6-months inception phase in 2018, the second year of the WACCA-Ethiopia programme included implementation under all proposed project outcomes, and within all three work packages (WP 1 - Meteorological and Climate Information Services; WP2 - Hydrological and Water Information Services; WP 3 Communication and Integration), and the two cross-cutting themes (Data management and ICT, and Gender Mainstreaming). Focus in 2019 has been on continued support to the Basins Development Authority (BDA) and its Hydrology and Water Quality Directorate (HWQD), the National Meterological Agency (NMA) and the Environment Forest and Climate Change Commission (EFCCC) with refining operational procedures and public services mandates. Gender mainstreaming training that includes all three partner organisations has been conducted, which has been done in close collaboration with SIWI (Stockholm International Water Institute). SMHI has during the year fulfilled all planned missions in Ethiopia and Sweden. Some highlights from project activities during 2019: - NMA and HWQD expert visit to SMHI to work with SMHI staff on weather forecast, modelling and early warning service routines and to strengthen strategic partnerships and showcase best practices. - Design and development of an SOP DokuWiki1 portal on the NMA intranet for further work in standardising NMA operations. - Training with focus on meteorological forecasting and climate modelling and information services at NMA. - Training in the field for improved hydrological monitoring, including instrumentation, data handling and safety at HWQD. - Training with focus on hydrological modelling and setting up a hydrological early warning system at HWQD. - Collaboration established between HWQD, SMHI and the World Meteorological Organisation (WMO) regarding use and support of WMO’s Meteorological, Climatological and Hydrological Database Management System2 (MCH) for storing and retrieving hydrological observations data at BDA. - Two local Ethiopian expert consultants have been contracted to complement the SMHI staff, a senior gender expert and a senior hydrologist, both of which are highly qualified with many years of relevant experience. - Workshops on data sharing have been conducted in Norrköping and Addis Ababa where participants preliminarily agreed – in principle – on what data to be shared when and in what quality, which is critical for improved water, weather and climate services. - Field visit near Hawassa with communication experts from NMA, MoWIE and the three BDA branch offices to discuss access to forecasts (short and long term) with agricultural extension agents and farmers, which was coordinated with the SIWI project field site selection for development synergy and to ensure consistency in outreach between projects. - NMA, MoWIE and BDA visited SMHI to continue with the communications work that begun in the field in Ethiopia and get further training on communication tools for use in disseminating information to agricultural extension agents, farmers and other stakeholders. - Collaboration framework established between SMHI and SIWI on conducting gender mainstreaming activities within each of the Ethiopian partner institutions. - Workshops on gender sensitisation, gender mainstreaming and sexual harassment in the workplace conducted with officers from MoWIE, BDA, EFCCC and NMA. - Procurement for the hydrological EWS (early warning system) equipment completed and shipped to Ethiopia as part of the development for hydrological early warning services. - Decisions taken for the use of a majority of the investment funds that will support the Ethiopian institutions with IT-related equipment for better data management and monitoring, and equipment for improved hydrological field operations. See statement of annual report for 2019 for further information.
